results.title: Preserving native grasslands
results.creator_credit: Conservation Forrest and Lands and Victoria. Dept of Conservation, Forests and Lands
results.brief_description: This program examines the problem of our disappearing native grasslands due to the urban sprawl, introduced species and weeds. The department of Conservation, Forests and Land have put out a booklet promoting public awareness of native plants (grasses, flowers and herbs), when and how to identify them, and the various steps involved in preserving them. No other credits available.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Conservation Forrest and Lands and Victoria. Dept of Conservation, Forests and Lands
results.description: This program examines the problem of our disappearing native grasslands due to the urban sprawl, introduced species and weeds. The department of Conservation, Forests and Land have put out a booklet promoting public awareness of native plants (grasses, flowers and herbs), when and how to identify them, and the various steps involved in preserving them. No other credits available.
description_for_label: This program examines the problem of our disappearing native grasslands due to the urban sprawl, introduced species and weeds. The department of Conservation, Forests and Land have put out a booklet promoting public awareness of native plants (grasses, flowers and herbs), when and how to identify them, and the various steps involved in preserving them. No other credits available.

results.title: Rachel; Just one of the kids
results.creator_credit: Tony Paice and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: 1. “Rachel” (40 min.) is the story of a young girl with a disability making her transition from a small rural community school to a large country technical school. 2. “Just one of the kids” (20 min.) shows the development of integration in the state school system.

results.title: From the beginning to the resistances
results.creator_credit: Mick Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘Me, my family, my nan - my mob.’ This is Mick Edwards’ story of separation, of a stolen generation or in Edwards’ words, “the kidnapped generation” and of healing and family and reunion.

results.title: More or less: a film about food
results.creator_credit: Lawrie Whittle, Paddy Stitt and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: Andrew Daddo outlines the “More or less” diet which is advocated by the Life Be In It campaign as a plan for eating for the “rest of your life”. By choosing carefully from the five basic food groups and eating more bread, cereals, fruit and vegetables, and less sugar, fat and salt, and exercising regularly, more children can became aware of the choices involved in planning a balanced diet.
results.title_for_label: More or less: a film about food
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lawrie Whittle, Paddy Stitt and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group

results.title: Mirror, mirror: girls, self esteem & physical activity

results.title: Return to Botany Bay
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris and Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch
results.brief_description: Intersperses 1987 documentary footage of the re-enactment of the voyage of the First Fleet with Trevor Lunn interviewing an Australia Post representative discussing their role in the Bi-centennial re-enactment and production of the commemorative stamp series.

results.title: Visions of perfection
results.creator_credit: Diane Charleson, Prahran School Support Centre and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: The Victoria College of the Arts provides a venue for talented children in the performing arts of music and dance to combine these with their academic studies in a high school setting. A student violinist, percussionist, ballet dancer and pianist talk about the courses available and demonstrate some of the activities in the school.

results.title: I'm home
results.creator_credit: Ron Briggs, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Identity is the most important thing to Ron Briggs. He talks about his father, his family and the traumatic experiences of being part of the stolen generation which separated him not only from his parents but also from his siblings.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ron Briggs, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
